headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Very focused on driving more and more costs out of the Wireline side on SG&A, absolutely. And on the back of the 11,000 volunteers we had on our East associate offer, I should mention that we are going to do some additional offers in the rest of Verizon i
componenttext: Very focused on driving more and more costs out of the Wireline side on SG&A, absolutely. And on the back of the 11,000 volunteers we had on our East associate offer, I should mention that we are going to do some additional offers in the rest of Verizon in the second half of the year in what used to be the West, which is really California, Texas and Florida. So we would expect to get some additional force reductions from that.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Simon Flannery of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Simon Flannery of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: On the dividend outlook, you've always had some strong cash flow performance. You've got a positive outlook for the second half of the year, but on the other hand, you also distributed a dividend effectively with Frontier with a lot of cash generation. So
componenttext: On the dividend outlook, you've always had some strong cash flow performance. You've got a positive outlook for the second half of the year, but on the other hand, you also distributed a dividend effectively with Frontier with a lot of cash generation. So how should we think about your upcoming decision in September around continuing that annual dividend increase? Or are there some sort of one-time factors this year? And then, we've had AT&T out with tier data pricing. You've got a lot of smartphone load now. LTEs coming up. What are your current thoughts on tiered data pricing?

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: So Simon, just a couple of thoughts for you. Yes, cash flow is tremendously strong, better in the quarter than even we expected. The team has a tremendous amount of effort and attention there. It's driven principally from operating performance. As part of
componenttext: So Simon, just a couple of thoughts for you. Yes, cash flow is tremendously strong, better in the quarter than even we expected. The team has a tremendous amount of effort and attention there. It's driven principally from operating performance. As part of that, though, is I hope you noticed the working capital benefits because the operating team is very focused on managing inventory levels and all of your days sales outstanding, all of the components that drive cash flow in the business, and I think we're performing extremely well here. So on the dividend side, and as you know, that's a board decision. The board will consider that in September. I think we put them in a position where they have some pretty good alternatives there from a dividend perspective given the cash flow performance. But at the end of the day, that will be their decision. On pricing, we're performing extremely well right now. If you look at our data revenues this quarter, they're up about 24% year-on-year. If you look at data ARPU for our postpaid base, they're up over 19%. Again, as I said to you earlier, a lot of upside potential there, given where we are on smartphones and multimedia devices in the future. We have indicated in the past, as we move to an LTE world and LTE pricing, we will probably look very hard at tiered pricing, and that continues to be our thinking right now. So more to come on that. By the way, I should say that all of our efforts, all of our plans on getting LTE launched in the fourth quarter are on schedule. We feel very good about that. We think that's going to open up a whole new set of opportunities to continue to grow this Wireless business that is, again, performing very well.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from David Barden of Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from David Barden of Bank of America.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: John, just first, could you talk a little bit about the one part of the Wireless that seemed to be maybe a little on the soft side, which was the retail prepaid? It seems like you guys have kind of transferred the economics of being a retail prepay provid
componenttext: John, just first, could you talk a little bit about the one part of the Wireless that seemed to be maybe a little on the soft side, which was the retail prepaid? It seems like you guys have kind of transferred the economics of being a retail prepay provider in Wireless over to your wholesale relationship with TracFone. That relationship has been on for a year now. I was wondering if you could kind of talk to us about your takeaways and some of the experiments you're doing with the $50 unlimited plan in the Southeast.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: So, Dave, overall from a growth perspective in Wireless, very satisfied, 1.4 million net adds. On the last quarter call, a lot of us, a lot of people were suggesting that the postpaid market was coming to its end. And we suggested to you we thought there
componenttext: So, Dave, overall from a growth perspective in Wireless, very satisfied, 1.4 million net adds. On the last quarter call, a lot of us, a lot of people were suggesting that the postpaid market was coming to its end. And we suggested to you we thought there was still a lot of life there for Verizon, and we did a lot better in the second quarter than we did in the first quarter. So we feel very good about our position in the postpaid marketplace. That is our prime strategy. Lowell and his team have done a tremendous job with the device lineup, the whole DROID franchise is performing extremely well. We introduced the Incredible, as you know, in the second quarter. We just launched the DROID X. There's more devices to come. So we think our handset lineup is very well positioned. Now we've also suggested that we've decided to play more of the prepaid marketplace, not exclusively. We have our own prepaid offerings that have benefits in terms of handsets and customer service but that we were playing more of that end of the market through the Reseller opportunity. By the way, not just the Straight Talk offering, there's several different retailers. And we've been very satisfied with that. I mean, it's fueled some nice growth for us as we've gone through the past year. The ARPU levels run significantly higher than the traditional Reseller offerings we have had. The profitability from a pure margin percentage basis is pretty good because you don't have the marketing costs and a lot of the SG&A. So we think that strategy has worked well for us, and we're continuing to do that. There's always some seasonal fluctuation there from a Reseller model. Now on the prepaid offering that you said, it's just a trial in the South. It's targeted to a specific geographic area. There's not a plan at the moment to bring that nationally. From time to time, our areas do different things to see what kind of reactions, kind of experiments and that's what that is all about, nothing more than that.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. If I could just follow up on the tiered pricing also, obviously, had a good quarter in postpaid. The new iPhone and the pricing changes came out at the end of second quarter. Now that you've had some time to kind of assess the market and what the ti
componenttext: Okay. If I could just follow up on the tiered pricing also, obviously, had a good quarter in postpaid. The new iPhone and the pricing changes came out at the end of second quarter. Now that you've had some time to kind of assess the market and what the tiered pricing plan has meant for AT&T versus you guys now without it, how compelling an offer do you feel it is? How competitively imperative is it that you do something along those lines? Or is it mostly just a capacity management, this kind of thing [ph] (0:56:53.2)?

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: It's very early days since that change went in. What I would tell you is our business continues to perform extremely well, that our smartphone lineup is being very well received. Our DROID lineup, we have trouble keeping the DROIDs in stock. By the way, w
componenttext: It's very early days since that change went in. What I would tell you is our business continues to perform extremely well, that our smartphone lineup is being very well received. Our DROID lineup, we have trouble keeping the DROIDs in stock. By the way, we don't have a big supply problem here. There's a little bit of a delay in fulfillment. But we're in a good position there. So our business is continuing to perform extremely well. You haven't seen us rush out to make any kind of a change. We'll continue to monitor the situation, of course, and look at opportunities that we'll say, "What's the best equation for us to drive long-term shareholder value?" and we'll be very focused on that. I can't say enough, though, about the opportunity we see ahead, given where we are today with smartphone penetration. I mean I think 20% of our base today, where's that number going? Ultimately, is it 80%? Some people could argue everyone's going to have smartphone ultimately because that's the kind of device it's going to be. So I think there's tremendous opportunity to continue to drive and create value through Verizon Wireless.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Michael Rollins of Citi Investment Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Michael Rollins of Citi Investment Research.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to follow up on the cost side, I think it was in the last call, you started to size the opportunity for cost cutting over the next two years, and if I remember correctly, the comment was at least $1.5 billion to $2 billion. Based on the effort
componenttext: Just wanted to follow up on the cost side, I think it was in the last call, you started to size the opportunity for cost cutting over the next two years, and if I remember correctly, the comment was at least $1.5 billion to $2 billion. Based on the efforts you've made in the second quarter, can you give us an update in terms of the size of the opportunity and what percent of that you think you could realize in 2010 versus 2011?

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: So Mike, I'm not going to resize the number for you. What I would tell you is, is our confidence on the ability to drive cost out of the entire business, both Wireline and in the Wireless business, too, has never been stronger. I mean I think we've come o
componenttext: So Mike, I'm not going to resize the number for you. What I would tell you is, is our confidence on the ability to drive cost out of the entire business, both Wireline and in the Wireless business, too, has never been stronger. I mean I think we've come off a quarter where we've had very good performance. If you look at our business year-on-year, we're down about 24,000 people in total from an absolute basis, a big chunk of those coming out in the first half of this year, more coming out in the second half of the year. By the way, we also transferred a little over 9,000 people with the Frontier transaction that we just completed. So I think we're in a very good position. The organization knows how important it is to resize the cost structure. So we feel very confident about our ability to do that.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Jason Armstrong of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Jason Armstrong of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: First on enterprise trends, the results seem to indicate share shifts in your favor. I'm wondering, you obviously talked about the macro, but can you talk about what you're seeing in the competitive marketplace? And then maybe second question just on Wire
componenttext: First on enterprise trends, the results seem to indicate share shifts in your favor. I'm wondering, you obviously talked about the macro, but can you talk about what you're seeing in the competitive marketplace? And then maybe second question just on Wireless ARPU, good progress on the postpaid ARPU growth, accelerating the rate of growth, as you moved up to 1.2%. But with the device refresh you've got going on, it seems like we have a lot more upside. So I'm just wondering if you can talk about trajectory from here and we see at least one peer in the industry approach 4% growth. Do you think that's realistic for you?

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Jason, a couple thoughts for you:  Yes, Enterprise, we had better performance this quarter. On a reported basis, we were up, which was very good. Now we had a couple of things that helped us there. We had a very strong CPE quarter, a lot of demand for equ
componenttext: Jason, a couple thoughts for you:  Yes, Enterprise, we had better performance this quarter. On a reported basis, we were up, which was very good. Now we had a couple of things that helped us there. We had a very strong CPE quarter, a lot of demand for equipment out there, which is good. I mean it drives some margin. We are doing some pricing change on the CPE lineup. We did it late second quarter, early third quarter to drive a little bit of margin. That might temper down the volume just a little bit, as we go through the third quarter. When you underlie and strip out CPE and some of the other things, we did see improved performance in Enterprise, although it was still a little bit negative year-over-year. I wouldn't say we're seeing any big change from an economic standpoint at this point. I think you're hearing that from every call that's out there right now is maybe in the first quarter, there was a little bit of an uptick with everything going on in Europe and other issues. There's probably been a little bit of a pause in terms of purchase decisions right now. We're hoping that will pick back up in the second half of the year. But from a pure Enterprise perspective, we were pleased with our performance in the quarter. But we have a little bit of caution as we go through the rest of the year and again, why it's so important to drive more and more costs out of the business. But at the same time, very focused on driving more profitability in Enterprise. In fact, as I looked at our deals we signed in the second quarter versus the first quarter, margin was up about 250 basis points on those deals quarter-to-quarter. So I think that was a very good sign. From a Wireless postpaid ARPU, we think there is upside as we go through the next couple years. Our smartphone lineup, if you think about it, over the last year, we've solved the problem with the DROID franchise, where we were a little bit behind in terms of the smartphone lineup. That is paying dividends for us right now. We expect those dividends to accelerate that our lineup is going to do extremely well. I'd love to see 3% to 4%. I think we will get better. I think the other company that you indicated, they do have a higher concentration of smartphones in their customer base than we do today. But that gap is going to close because we've got great devices, great lineup, and of course, our distribution is a machine quarter after quarter. So I think you're going to see improving performance there. And it just comes back to the issue I said earlier is we believe there's tremendous opportunity to continue to drive shareholder value in this business, fueled principally on the Wireless side.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Brett Feldman of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Brett Feldman of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to go back quickly here to Wireless margins. You gave a lot of color earlier about what you're doing, particularly on the cost management side.  You're coming in at like I think an all-time record this quarter in terms of EBITDA margin. And I
componenttext: Just wanted to go back quickly here to Wireless margins. You gave a lot of color earlier about what you're doing, particularly on the cost management side.  You're coming in at like I think an all-time record this quarter in terms of EBITDA margin. And I just wanted to maybe get a bit more color around what the ultimate goal here is. The cost savings initiatives, is that designed to sort of help you guys sustain what is a margin level that's maybe 200, 300 basis points higher than normally people would have expected? Or are you really just trying to create capacity so that you can keep your foot on the gas in terms of driving data in terms of incurring the subsidies that you would get from higher smartphone sales and maybe the higher costs you're eventually going to incur from running the LTE network?

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Look, I think from a Wireless perspective, we've always been a very balanced company in terms of not just looking at top line, not just looking at growth, really looking at all the levers to drive shareholder value. We still are in the same place. So we'r
componenttext: Look, I think from a Wireless perspective, we've always been a very balanced company in terms of not just looking at top line, not just looking at growth, really looking at all the levers to drive shareholder value. We still are in the same place. So we're going to have a lot of focus. And I've said this -- since I've been on this job, I've said I think there is opportunity to continue to grow the Wireless business very nicely, and we think growth is going to accelerate, right? We think there's not going to be a deceleration in growth; there's actually going to be a next wave fueled by data and video, where growth is going to get better. But at the same time, we have the opportunity to take costs out of the model and become a more efficient provider, and Lowell and his team are extremely focused on that. So I like our position here from a Wireless perspective and where we have the ability to go.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: I think, just to be a little bit more specific, I mean, you're doing a great job with smartphones. A little bit over half your sales in your direct channel now are smartphones or other integrated devices. But based in your lineup, you could easily see tha
componenttext: I think, just to be a little bit more specific, I mean, you're doing a great job with smartphones. A little bit over half your sales in your direct channel now are smartphones or other integrated devices. But based in your lineup, you could easily see that at 70% or 80% in the not-too-distant future. You're probably going to be incurring some additional costs as you get ramped on LTE. I'm just trying to set expectations here in that should we assume that, at some point, that might create a little bit of incremental pressure on the margins? Or do you really feel comfortable that what you've done from a cost management side can kind of keep things in a range, even as you ramp in those areas?

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: I feel very comfortable that we can both grow the top line of the business and continue to deliver the industry-leading profitability that we have delivered. There's no question there's going to be a higher take-up of smartphones and multimedia devices, b
componenttext: I feel very comfortable that we can both grow the top line of the business and continue to deliver the industry-leading profitability that we have delivered. There's no question there's going to be a higher take-up of smartphones and multimedia devices, but we're very well positioned for that. There's also a nice return from that because they're higher ARPU-based customers. So I don't think anyone's network, anyone's distribution is better positioned to take advantage and drive it to the bottom line than we are, and we're very focused on that.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Tim Horan of Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Tim Horan of Oppenheimer.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: One of your major competitors when they started rolling out smartphones, they saw the margins get depressed quite a bit. You're not seeing that now and it sounds like you don't expect to see that. Is it because the DROID maybe has a lot lower subsidies th
componenttext: One of your major competitors when they started rolling out smartphones, they saw the margins get depressed quite a bit. You're not seeing that now and it sounds like you don't expect to see that. Is it because the DROID maybe has a lot lower subsidies than -- sort of the DROID lineup than some of the other high-end smartphones out there? And secondly, could you just give us maybe a little bit more -- and on that point, it sounds like you're saying that you're not going to see any supply chain problems with the DROID lineup in the second half of the year. Maybe just comment on that. And then just lastly, can you give us a bit of a regulatory update? Are you guys talking to the FCC about ways to avoid the Title II regulation discussions that are ongoing? That will be helpful.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: So, Tim, smartphone subsidy levels -- because smartphone devices cost you more money, our COGS is up but it's a nice trade-off here. And if you look at our machine in terms of what we built over time, we have the ability to manage that and absorb it and s
componenttext:
So, Tim, smartphone subsidy levels -- because smartphone devices cost you more money, our COGS is up but it's a nice trade-off here. And if you look at our machine in terms of what we built over time, we have the ability to manage that and absorb it and still drive good margins, and we believe we can. Now if we had one quarter where we had 3 million DROID net adds, there's probably going to be a little bit of an impact. But by the way, I would take that impact because of what's it's going to do ultimately for value and shareholder value. So we're focused, as we've always said, both on growth and profitability. We will continue to be focused on that. We are taking costs out of our supply chain process, and we will continue to do that. We're managing inventory levels extremely tightly, which is appropriate. From a supply chain perspective on supply of smartphones, we need to manage through it, which we are. These are kind of global issues with certain devices, but we're in a good position here. We think we can fulfill the requirements we have as we go through the second half of the year. We're working extremely closely with all of our manufacturers, and we think we're extremely well positioned. The other comment I'd make here, Tim, on the Washington front, yes, we're actively, actively engaged, including Ivan and Tom Tauke and Randy Milch on all of the issues, both with the policymakers as well as other industry participants. And we'll continue to watch this, and we're optimistic that this will come out in the right place for us and for the industry. But time will tell on that. So not a lot more that I could comment on there right now. 
So I just want to add one other thought here for you before we close off is we did complete the Frontier transaction. I know you're all anxious for pro formas. We'll get that out to you. But as we look back on that, that was a very, very good transaction for us and for Verizon. When we first announced the deal, there were about 4.8 million lines in those territories. As you know, we had a fixed value effectively. The value per line was about $1,791. By the time we completed the transaction, it was about $22,140 per line. So we're very satisfied with what we've done with the Frontier transaction, and we think we've gotten very good value here for the Verizon shareholder, both in terms of the value they get from Frontier and the debt relief. So it's a transaction we're very pleased with. And our team, I think, did an outstanding job working with Frontier around all of the [ph] (1:10:36.2) transition. I would also like to just publicly acknowledge Ron on this call. Many of you did that, but he's done a terrific job for us over the last several years. We will be announcing his replacement shortly in August. And I think it will be a top-notch individual. And of course, that individual will have the guidance of Ron on what needs to be done here. So Ron, I'd just like to thank you, and I know from the industry, you'll be getting a lot of thanks.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-23-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you very much, John, and, Brad, that concludes our call today. And thanks, everybody, for joining us.
componenttext: Thank you very much, John, and, Brad, that concludes our call today. And thanks, everybody, for joining us.
