headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning and welcome to the Verizon Third Quarter, 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to turn the call over to your host, Mr. John Doherty, Senior Vice President Investor Relations for Verizon.
componenttext: Good morning and welcome to the Verizon Third Quarter, 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] It is now my pleasure to turn the call over to your host, Mr. John Doherty, Senior Vice President Investor Relations for Verizon.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning and welcome to our third quarter, 2010 Earnings Conference Call. Thanks for joining us this morning, I'm John Doherty. With me this morning is John Killian, our Chief Financial Officer; and Fran Shammo , who will be assuming the CFO role on N
componenttext:
Good morning and welcome to our third quarter, 2010 Earnings Conference Call. Thanks for joining us this morning, I'm John Doherty. With me this morning is John Killian, our Chief Financial Officer; and Fran Shammo , who will be assuming the CFO role on November 1.
Before we get started, let me remind you that our earnings release, financial statements, the investor quarterly publication and the presentation slides are available on our Investor Relations website. This call is being webcast. If you would like to listen to a replay, you can do so from our website. I would also like to draw your attention to our Safe Harbor Statement. Information in this presentation contains statements about expected future events and financial results that are forward-looking and subject to risks and uncertainties. Discussion of factors that may affect future result is contained in Verizon's filings with the SEC, which are available on our website. This presentation also contains certain non-GAAP financial measures. Reconciliations of these non-GAAP measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures are also on our website.
As I am sure you are aware, we published, reclassified historical financial information for the past six quarters with results associated with the Frontier transaction as well as the divested Wireless trust properties. In addition we have reclassified prior period Wireless results for the deferred revenue adjustment that we recognized in the second quarter of 2010. The financial and operating metrics included in our slides are therefore presented on a comparable basis. However, on the balance sheets and statements of cash flows, prior periods were not reclassified for the impact of the divested properties.
On a GAAP basis, we reported earnings of $0.31 per share in the third quarter. This quarterly results include a total of $0.25 of nonoperational charges, which are listed on Slide 4. The largest item is a non-cash charge of $0.19 per share relating to the recognition of pension settlement losses resulting from our workforce reduction and separation plan. Pension accounting rules require that settlement losses must be recorded once prescribed payment specials have been reached. In connection with the closing of the Frontier spin-off, we also incurred a charge of $0.04 per share for certain non-operational and transaction related costs. 
The last item is merger integration costs related to Alltel. During the third quarter, charges related to these activities amounted to $0.02 per share. With that, I'll now turn the call over to John Killian.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John, and good morning, everyone. Before we get into the details, let me start with some comments on our overall performance and add some of my perspectives to our third quarter results. The business is performing extremely well. We had another so
componenttext:
Thanks, John, and good morning, everyone. Before we get into the details, let me start with some comments on our overall performance and add some of my perspectives to our third quarter results. The business is performing extremely well. We had another solid quarter and we continue to execute well in our key focus areas. We had strong earnings performance in the quarter, showing sequential improvement. On our last conference call, I stated that our goal was to grow earnings in the second half of the year by 5% to 10% from our first half adjusted base of $1.01 per share. Our third quarter results indicate that we are on track to meet this goal and expect to be at the high-end of this guidance.
Wireless had a very good quarter with accelerating revenue growth driven by strong postpaid ARPU accretion. New customer additions and device upgrades once again resulted in higher smartphones sales and drove data revenue increases. And we sustained our Wireless EBITDA margin of 47.02% which remains by far the highest in the industry. In Wireline we continue to make steady progress. We had a very strong quarter of customer growth in FiOS with our third consecutive quarter of sequential improvement, adding more than 200,000 new customers in both TV and Internet, our highest net add totals since the second quarter of 2009.
Revenues in global enterprise were stable, showing modest sequential improvement and while the Wireline revenue picture is essentially unchanged, we were able to improve our EBITDA margin on a sequential basis, coming in more than 20 basis points higher than last quarter at 21%. We'll talk more about this in a few minutes but we feel confident that our workforce and other cost reduction efforts have stabilized Wireline profitability and we should continue to see these benefits in the fourth quarter.
In terms of cash generation, we had another outstanding quarter. Our improved business performance and tight controls on capital have resulted in significant increases in free cash flow for the first nine months of the year and our focus on reducing leverage has improved our key credit metrics and strength in the balance sheet. I'd also highlight that our Board of Directors approved a 2.6% dividend increase in September which on an annual basis is an increase from $1.90 to $1.95 a share. This marks the fourth consecutive year of dividend increases. So all in all we're pleased with our continued strong performance. 
Let's now move to our more detailed review of the quarter, starting with some financial highlights on Slide 4.
Reported earnings for the quarter were $0.31 per share. The non-operational charges amounted to $0.25 so you can see that gets us to a $0.56 and quarterly results. So we're building solid earnings momentum. I would point out that we saw about a $0.01 EPS benefit in the third quarter due to a lower effective tax rate close to the Frontier spin-off. For the full year 2010, absent any further significant tax law changes, you should expect that the adjusted effective tax rate attributable to Verizon will be in the 31% to 32% range. Consolidated top line growth accelerated to 2.1% year-over-year and drove an 8.3% increase in operating income. Our adjusted EBITDA margin also expanded 130 basis points to 33.4% and cash flow continues to be very strong.
One additional point on earnings. We are seeing sequential improvement. Slide 5 shows our quarterly earnings on a comparable basis, so our $0.56 per share this quarter is a 7.7% improvement over the second quarter. Let's spend a few more minutes on cash flow, dividends, capital spending and debt on Slide 6. Cash flow from operations in the third quarter totaled $8.3 billion and free cash flow was $4.2 billion. On a year-to-date basis, cash flow from operations of $25.2 billion is up 9.1% and free cash flow of $13.4 billion is up $2.7 billion or 25.3%. 
In addition, we received $3.1 billion in cash from the Frontier transaction in early July that we used to reduce debt and a cash distribution of about $440 million from Omnitel this quarter. As I highlighted earlier, our Board approved a dividend increase for the fourth consecutive year demonstrating their confidence in the strength of our cash flow and balance sheet and our commitment to return cash to shareholders. In addition our shareholders received $1.85 per share and valued through the Frontier transaction in July. I can assure you that we have adequate dividend coverage based on our cash flow and our capital spending outlook. We had no material funding requirement for our qualified pension plans in 2010. And as is customary, we fund our other post-retirement benefit plans on a pay-as-you-go basis out of operating cash flows.
Looking at capital, we spent $4.2 billion during the third quarter, which was 4.5% less than a year ago. On a year-to-date basis, total CapEx was $11.8 billion, 4.9% below the first nine months of last year. During the year we have effectively reallocated capital between our operating segments reflecting growth opportunities. In Wireless, capital spending is higher than last year driven by four 4G LTE deployment and network capacity requirements. 
Wireless CapEx totaled $6.2 billion year-to-date, which is an increase of $1.1 billion or about 21%. In Wireline, capital spending is down reflecting lower FiOS deployment capital as planned and our type focus on spending to increase free cash flow. Wireline CapEx was $5.1 billion year-to-date, a decrease of $1.5 billion or 23%. Looking ahead, we expect that our total capital spending for the year will be at the low end or slightly below our targeted range of $16.8 billion to $17.2 billion for 2010. 
In terms of the balance sheet, a top priority has been to reduce leverage, we're doing very well here with net debt of $47.8 billion at the end of the third quarter, down $12.5 billion or 20.7% since the beginning of the year. Our net debt to adjusted EBITDA ratio has improved to about 1.4x and we expect to be even lower by the end of the year.
Let's take a look at our revenue trends which are on Slide 7. Our overall revenue performance is improving and we saw an acceleration of growth in the third quarter on a comparable basis. Consolidated quarterly revenues of $26.5 billion were up by $550 million or 2.1% from a year ago. Growth was driven by solid performance in all our strategic areas which comprised roughly 2/3 of our total revenue. We'll get into more detail at the segment level but we saw an uptick in Wireless service revenue growth driven, of course, by strong data performance. We had a very good quarter in FiOS with year-over-year revenue growth of more than 29% and growth in strategic enterprise services is accelerating up nearly 7%. With that high-level summary of revenues, let's move to the segments next starting Wireless on Slide 8.
Our Wireless business turned in another very good quarter, particularly with respect to revenue growth. Total revenue grew to $16.3 billion in the quarter, up $919 million or 6% year-over-year. And growth in total service revenue accelerated to 7.7% in the third quarter, our highest year-over-year growth rate since the second quarter of 2009. Our continued focus on expanding the market for mobile broadband grow data revenue to $5.1 billion this quarter, up 26.3% over the last year, that's more than $1 billion of growth in just one year. 
We continue to make excellent progress in terms of increasing our smartphone penetration with 23% of our retail postpaid base with these devices. We feel very good about our current portfolio of smart phones and we build great momentum in a short period of time with the Droid franchise. Our recent announcement to begin selling Apple iPads at our retail locations is designed to stimulate sales of our MiFi devices which have already become quite popular with customers. 
We are performing well in this very competitive marketplace but as confident as we are about our ability to compete today, we're even more excited about the future. Earlier this month at a CTIA event in San Francisco, Lowell McAdam announced Phase I 4G LTE launch locations. Our plan is to cover more than 110 million POPs in 38 major metropolitan areas and 62 airports by the end of this year. And the next phase will expand coverage to about 200 million POPs over the next 18 months. 
By the end of 2013, we'll have virtually the same nationwide coverage we have today on 3G. With Wireless data revenue exceeding $5 billion this quarter, it's hard to believe that we're still in the early earnings in terms of this revenue growth opportunity, but we are. We are very excited about mobile broadband and we believe the growing interest in smartphones, tablets and other devices signals a new wave of growth for the industry. With the commercial launch of LTE just around the corner, we are extremely well-positioned in this expanding market. We firmly believe that our network advantage will become even more of a differentiator for Verizon given the consistent and substantial investment in our Wireless network over many years.
Let's now turn to our customer and connections results on Slide 9.  We had a solid quarter of growth, adding about $1 million net new customers and about 250,000 of connections. In the retail postpaid market, we have 584,000 net adds and a strong quarter in terms of device sales. Retail postpaid gross adds in the quarter were up 9.8% sequentially and device upgrades were also higher. 
Our performance in the reseller channel was also very good, with 550,000 net adds this quarter. As we've said before the reseller market continues to be a low-cost channel for us and an effective way for us to attract incremental prepaid customers. We ended the quarter with $93.2 million total customers, with 88% of the base being retail postpaid, 5% retail prepaid and 7% reseller. In terms of other connections, we have a total of 7.9 million machine-to-machine connections which include vehicle tracking and telematics. 
Let's take a closer look at our retail performance on Slide 10.
As you know our key focus is on the retail postpaid market, where we continue to drive revenue growth by increasing data usage and driving higher smartphone penetration. Retail service revenues in the quarter grew 5% year-over-year. Retail postpaid ARPU increased 2% compared with a year ago, sharply higher than the year-over-year accretion we saw in each of the first two quarters of this year. As I mentioned a moment ago, we had another strong quarter of overall device sales of about 9.5% of our existing postpaid customers upgrading to a newer device. Our highest level since the fourth quarter last year. Our churn metrics, although a bit higher than the second quarter due to seasonality, were excellent once again this quarter. Retail postpaid churn was 1.07% and total churn was 1.36%.
In terms of smartphone sales, we now have 23% of our retail postpaid base with these devices, that's up substantially from last year and there's plenty of headroom left. About 43% of device sales from our direct channels this quarter were smartphones, taking into account both gross adds and upgrades. And 60% of our existing postpaid customers buying smartphones were new to the category. So this is significant in terms of incremental data revenue for us.
Revenue from Web and email services increased to more than $2.7 billion this quarter, up about 43% from a year ago. Messaging, which makes up about 36% of data revenue, is still showing good growth, up 11% on a year-over-year basis. And we've made rapid progress in a relatively short period of time adding 8.4 million smartphone customers, an increasing data ARPU by 17.6% in the past 12 months. We believe penetration and data ARPU growth could really explode over the next several years, particularly in light of the growth opportunities in front of us with LTE.
In terms of profitability, we had another excellent quarter, generating $6.7 billion of EBITDA, up 11.4% from a year ago. Our third quarter service EBITDA margin was 47.2%, driven by strong data revenues, churn improvement and the continued benefit of Alltel synergies. Looking ahead, you can expect us to continue achieving both growth and profitability with a focus on gaining share on the retail postpaid market and increasing the penetration of smart phones and other data devices, which will drive continued data revenue growth. 
Let's move to our Wireline segment on Slide 13.
On the consumer side, our of broadband and video products continue to drive a significant shift in our revenue mix. FiOS revenue at the quarter grew 29.2% year-over-year and FiOS ARPU, which now exceeds $146, is up more than 6% over the third quarter last year. On the enterprise side, we had a second consecutive quarter of sequential revenue improvement and growth and strategic services, which includes security, IP and other manage solutions, continues strength on the revenue mix. In global wholesale, revenues continue to be impacted by the effect of some international price changes on specific routes, which we're introduced last quarter to better manage margins.
Let's take a closer look at the consumer and business markets starting on Slide 14.
This time last year FiOS made up about 40% of consumer revenue. At the end of the third quarter it was up to 50%.  The increasing scales of FiOS and the strength of the broadband and video product is driving positive revenue and ARPU growth in mitigating the secular and competitive pressures in this part of the business. 
Consumer revenue in the quarter grew 1.1% versus last year, we continue to see strong growth in consumer ARPU, which increased to $86.55 this quarter, up 10.9% from a year ago. As I've said earlier we have strong sequential customer growth, adding about 19% more FiOS customers this quarter to our TV services and about 17% more to our Internet product compared with last quarter. We ended the third quarter with a total of 3.3 million FiOS TV customers, adding 204,000 compared with the 172,000 in the second quarter. 
On the broadband side, we added 226 sites of new FiOS that connect customers, compared with 193,000 last quarter, bringing our total to 23.9 million. Adding in a high-speed Internet or DSL customers, we ended the quarter with a total of 8.3 million broadband connections.
Underlying the strong performance is the fact that our FiOS customer satisfaction is very high and our churn rates are very low, so we are pleased with the progress we're making with FiOS, financially, operationally and competitively.
The good news about our success in penetration increases this quarter is that the improvements are evident throughout our entire FiOS footprint. Our focus have shifted from a geographic expansion mode to a focus on sales mode. Our goal is to increase FiOS penetration in markets where the services are already available and close the gap between homes passed and homes open for sale. We went to by nationwide, no contract required, worry-free guarantee has helped sales particularly in the MDU market where our apartment dwellers in large urban cities tend to be more transient and maybe more hesitant to sign two-year contracts, and we focused on marketing message to emphasize our product differentiation. This focus on sales and increasing penetration is paying off. In our more mature FiOS market we're still seeing consistent penetration gains, penetration in some of these markets is an excess of 35% and a few are in excess of 40% penetration. As you expect, in our less mature markets, we have significantly more room to grow. So we're more optimistic about our ability to further increase penetration and continue our growth path over the next several years. 
Let's move next to our business markets on Slide 16 which shows our global enterprise and global wholesale revenue performance. While revenues in the business market continue to be affected by macro economic pressures, we are seeing some signs of. stability. Global enterprise revenue of $3.9 billion was up modestly on a sequential basis and down .8% year-over-year, primarily due to foreign currency effects and while the quarter once again included strong CPE sales, we also saw improvements in revenue from network and solutions-based services. 
Strategic services, which now represent about 43% of global enterprise revenue, grew 6.9% year-over-year and 3.1% sequentially. Strategic networking like Private IP and ethernet services continued to show steady growth as due strategic solutions. So again we are seeing some signs of stabilization but we're still cautious in our optimism as usage volumes and unemployment figures have not shown any significant change. 
In global wholesale revenues declined 10.2% year-over-year and 1.3% sequentially. Domestically voice revenues continue to be impacted by secular pressures and lower usage volumes. Internationally we made a decision earlier this year to increase voice pricing in certain roots which has resulted in some loss of business in the highly competitive market. While the strategy has resulted in revenue declines, it's having the desired effect of absolute margins on most routes have improved sequentially. 
Let's cover Wireline profitability next. In the third quarter, EBITDAR increased by $31 million resulting in a more than 20 basis points sequential improvement in our EBITDA margin to 21%. With total revenue remaining essentially flat sequentially, almost all of the improvement this quarter was once again driven by cost reductions primarily wage related savings and third-party interconnection costs. Our workforce reduction initiative is preceding as planned. Wireline headcount was down 5,900 this quarter and is declined by about 10,500 over the past two quarters. As you know a majority of these reductions relate to our voluntary separation effort in the east and middle Atlantic regions. With about another 1,000 volunteers in other regions, we expect another 2,000 to 3,000 employees will leave our payroll by the end of the year. 
In terms of workforce reductions in the third quarter, we estimate the savings to be about $80 million, partially offsetting these cost savings this quarter were acquisition costs related to higher FiOS customer volumes and some typical seasonal increases including higher energy costs.
Lastly in terms of our other cost reduction initiatives, we are focused on capturing additional savings of real estate, network convergence, supply chain and inventory management. We have a well-organized and realistic plan and we are confident in our execution strategy.
To sum up, we had another very solid quarter across the entire business resulting in improved earnings and solid momentum. To reiterate, we're on track to achieve our goal of growing earnings in the second half of this year by 5% to 10% from our first half adjusted base of $1.01 per share. Our Wireless results were solid across the Board. We remain confident in our ability to grow the business by adding new customers and driving higher smartphone adoption leading to higher postpaid ARPU and improved revenue growth. And with a demonstrated ability to manage our costs, we continue to grow profitably, sustaining a very strong service EBITDA margin, even with higher volumes and more upgrades than last quarter. In our Wireline business, even though we're not getting any help from the economy and we don't expect to for the rest of this year, our cost reduction programs have stabilized Wireline profitability and we are optimistic about our opportunities to expand margins going forward. 
As always, we will continue to focus on maximizing free cash flow, maintaining a strong balance sheet and reducing debt. We are excited about our opportunities relating to our launch of 4G LTE services and Wireless and we're certainly very confident in the long term potential of the business. With that I'll turn it back to John so that we can get to your questions.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, John. Brad, we're now ready for questions.
componenttext: Thank you, John. Brad, we're now ready for questions.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Jason Armstrong of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Jason Armstrong of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: First on Wireless ARPU, this is the fourth quarter we've seen an accelerating postpaid ARPU growth and just thinking through these increases in smartphone penetration, would seem to really give you a good runway for further improvements in the rate of ARP
componenttext: First on Wireless ARPU, this is the fourth quarter we've seen an accelerating postpaid ARPU growth and just thinking through these increases in smartphone penetration, would seem to really give you a good runway for further improvements in the rate of ARPU growth from here, I'm just wondering is that how you would think about it as well and then second question on FiOS, good uptick in both FiOS video and data adds, when thinking about the increase, could you just help us think through is this attached to seasonal, is the no-contract moves you've made and ultimately what I think we're trying to get to is this kind of new level that we should give the run rate going forward?

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jayson, it's John. I'll take the first part of the question on ARPU and then Fran will cover the FiOS performance. We are very pleased with what's happening with ARPU. When you look at our postpaid ARPU this quarter we were up 2% in the third quarter, if
componenttext: Jayson, it's John. I'll take the first part of the question on ARPU and then Fran will cover the FiOS performance. We are very pleased with what's happening with ARPU. When you look at our postpaid ARPU this quarter we were up 2% in the third quarter, if you look at the last four quarters, fourth quarter '09, we were flat, we went to .6%, in the first quarter we went to 1.5%. It may seem that I've had on these clauses, we believe there's a lot of upside ahead of us and we have great ability to grow postpaid ARPU because of the explosion in smartphones. We've put a lot of energy, Lowell McAdam, John Stratton, Denby and their team on enhancing our smartphone portfolio. We've had great success over the last year with the Droid franchise and the BlackBerry lineup and others but we are in a much better position. But the good news here is, only 23% of our customers today have a smartphone, that's up from 20 last quarter. So you think about this, I don't know where it's going to end up but personally I think, we're going to look someday back and say 70% to 80% of your customers are going to have smartphones. So we think there is tremendous opportunity here and you know better than I do, Jason, smartphone customers spend about double what a feature phone customer spends with you. We also believe even on the feature phone side, more and more customers will buy data plans over time even before, as they have gotten used to data on the Wireless side, so start with a plan on a feature phones so we think there's tremendous opportunity here to grow top line in the Wireless business and you can see that coming through an accelerating revenue growth in the Wireless business. Fran, I'll turn it to you on FiOS.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: So talk about the FiOS adds and the broadband adds, we're very pleased with the strong performance that we had this quarter. If you look at some of the questions you asked, Jason, on the no contract, as John has spoken in the past in the MDU space, we wer
componenttext: So talk about the FiOS adds and the broadband adds, we're very pleased with the strong performance that we had this quarter. If you look at some of the questions you asked, Jason, on the no contract, as John has spoken in the past in the MDU space, we were under penetrated there. We've made a lot of moves including the no contract but we also made a move on the contract where we offer a worry-free guarantee similar to the Wireless side of the house that if you're not totally satisfied, we will let you out of the contract with no early termination fee. We also have launched a what we call a triple play in the MDU space understanding that a lot of this space is the younger adults segment which if you look at the triple play that we've launched, its broadband, its TV and it's Wireless rather than a Wireline connection. So we found that's also stimulating some growth in the MDU segment. When you expand that, the no contract definitely has had a very good growth perspective for us but we've also launched something new in our enterprise space where we're going to our enterprise customers and very similar to what we do on the Wireless side with employee liable accounts, we are signing up enterprise customers to promote our FiOS product within their employee base, so that has also stimulated some growth for us. So to wrap this up, yes, we feel that this level of adds is where we want to continue to be.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from John Hodulik of UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from John Hodulik of UBS.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the wireless data pricing strategy, guys, you recently made some changes or there are some in the past, and I guess I was surprised that you left the unlimited data plan out there. Is that a part of your strategy to increase the penetration of smart ph
componenttext: On the wireless data pricing strategy, guys, you recently made some changes or there are some in the past, and I guess I was surprised that you left the unlimited data plan out there. Is that a part of your strategy to increase the penetration of smart phones? Is that pricing potentially subject to change once you move to 4G and you potentially see data volumes grow and then secondly on the Wireline margin, it seems like you may have arrested the decline and you starting to see some improvement, sounds like fourth quarter you see some sequential improvement and then is that something that we can see improve from here as we head out? Is there enough cost-cutting opportunity for us to see improvements in 2011?

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Again I will take the first part of this question and then Fran will talk about the Wireline margin. I think what you were referring to, John, is some of the blog reports and some of the newspaper stories, we have not formally announced any change in data
componenttext: Again I will take the first part of this question and then Fran will talk about the Wireline margin. I think what you were referring to, John, is some of the blog reports and some of the newspaper stories, we have not formally announced any change in data pricing but we will be rolling out a data promotion next week focused on the fourth quarter. As we think about data pricing here, and just to give you little things to think about as we position this for the future, our aim here is really at expanding the market opportunity. We think there's a huge opportunity to continue to grow, we have a $20 billion annual Wireless data business, $5 billion a quarter. It's hard to describe that as early innings but we still believe it's the early innings of the data explosion. Also we are very focused at looking at opportunities to expand this opportunity, bring more of our base into data plans. The other thing to think about here is we believe we have built over time because of what we've done both with network investment, our advertising programs, a superior brand position that allows us to be unique in how we approach the market place from a data pricing, unique from what other companies do because of the brand position that we have built over time. Our fourth quarter promotion that we will have will have, really two key elements, we will continue to have unlimited plan, the $29 plan, the $30 plan, effectively, that is unlimited. So we'll also have a $15 plan and with the $15 plan you will be able to get 150 megabits of usage. But what we believe is that people who are new to category will probably buy the $15 plan but over time, you'll see much more migration to the higher end because there will be a lot of usage that will drive above the $150 megabits. So we think we're in a very good position. In the past, John, we're encouraged by tiered pricing, we liked the concept of tier pricing, you could interpret this a little bit as they move in that direction although we had the $9.99 plan before but we will continue to look at this and we probably will have some pricing changes when we roll out 4G and 4G pricing so there will be more to come then. And then we'll now talk about the Wireline margin.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: So on the Wireline margin, John. As John has spoken in the past, we do believe we stabilized. We do believe that we can continue to expand the margin and Wireline business. I would say that this is a two-pronged strategy, one is obviously top line growth
componenttext: So on the Wireline margin, John. As John has spoken in the past, we do believe we stabilized. We do believe that we can continue to expand the margin and Wireline business. I would say that this is a two-pronged strategy, one is obviously top line growth and I think that it's important to know that we reach an inflection point this quarter where FiOS is now 50% of our consumer revenues, so as we continue to improve the consumer ARPU 10% this quarter year-over-year, that will drive bottom-line growth. I think it's also important to state that on the enterprise side, we've seen stabilization. However, outside the United States, in our global markets we're seeing double-digit growth especially in the Asia Pac region and some other area parts of the world, so again that is more top line. But as we get into the cost and productivity and sustainability. As John has spoken in the past, we had an incentive offer for associates, we had 12,000 associates except that offer, about 80% of them have left the payroll to date. We will do more of that in the fourth quarter but it's also important to know that as we attack the cost side of the Wireline business , it's more than just the headcount reductions, it's quarter to quarter improvement and our operating metrics, especially when you look at FiOS and our cost to connect PRIM and our cost to connect video, if you look at our COA, our COA alone year-over-year has gone down 19% and with that reduction we've increased our adds. So it's a whole program of cost reduction. I believe it's sustainable and while we're doing that, we're improving our productivity so that when the economy and the enterprise restores and we continue on the track that we're in FiOS, we will continue to produce more margin.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Simon Flannery of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Simon Flannery of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: You touched on the LTE introduction. Could you help us understand what other impacts there might be in terms of expense recognition or interest capitalization anything around that. And as you roll out the LTE from the 110 million into this over 200 millio
componenttext: You touched on the LTE introduction. Could you help us understand what other impacts there might be in terms of expense recognition or interest capitalization anything around that. And as you roll out the LTE from the 110 million into this over 200 million plus, are we at sort of a steady state level here on Wireless CapEx where you're at a run rate or could there be a reduction or a lower intensity in '11 as the heavy lifting for that first 38 markets has already been done?

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we're very pleased with where we are in terms of the LTE deployment. We mentioned getting 110 million POPs by the end of this year, I've talked to Tony Malone as recently as yesterday to get an update on status and all systems are go. The network
componenttext: I think we're very pleased with where we are in terms of the LTE deployment. We mentioned getting 110 million POPs by the end of this year, I've talked to Tony Malone as recently as yesterday to get an update on status and all systems are go. The network will be in extremely good shape. From a normal customer acquisition and maintenance and  those kinds of things I think you are going to see the same kind of run rates looking ahead as you have seen, as we go into this year. I don't think you are going to see a major delta at all, in fact, we would argue over time that there will be more efficiency driven by LTE because the cost of megabits served is much lower with LTE than it is with EVDO and other technology. So we think that will position us well. There will be some impact from -- we have been capitalizing some interest, it's not a huge number, but we will see some impact as we go into 2011. Maybe a little bit in the fourth quarter but not a major delta there. From a CapEx perspective, what I would think about here is, and on this call we've said we're going to come in at the low end of our range or slightly below, I think we have a good chance of being slightly in below our guidance range on CapEx. You should think Wireless probably at about the same level next year as its running this year, in that kind of a range, when you look this year all of increase we've had has really been for the most part both on LTE as well as capacity for data, there have been other offsets, things like synergy capital will be going down, So I think it'll be a very controllable level of Wireless CapEx. The nice thing here is the CapEx to revenue ratio in the Wireless business runs quite a bit lower than the Wireline business and there is a lot of efficiency from that capital. So I think our cash flow numbers should continue to be strong.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Rollins of Citi Investment Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Rollins of Citi Investment Research.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on that more specifically on the Wireline side,  how should we think capital going into next year as the pace of new FiOS homes passed continues to slow? And then coming back on the Wireless side, I noticed the replacement rate what aroun
componenttext: Just a follow-up on that more specifically on the Wireline side,  how should we think capital going into next year as the pace of new FiOS homes passed continues to slow? And then coming back on the Wireless side, I noticed the replacement rate what around 9.5% and smartphones have become a larger part of your base and enhanced the larger percent of the replacement volumes, how should we be thinking about the incremental costs related to that in other areas that you can identify to maybe offset some of that upward pressure from just a greater pace of smartphone replacements overtime?

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of thoughts for you here, Mike. We're not in the position yet to give any guidance on CapEx for next year, but as I think about this, and certainly Fran will be talking about this in January, I think the direction of overall CapEx spending, and w
componenttext: A couple of thoughts for you here, Mike. We're not in the position yet to give any guidance on CapEx for next year, but as I think about this, and certainly Fran will be talking about this in January, I think the direction of overall CapEx spending, and we've set this in the past, is down from where we are today. I'm not going to quantify that exactly but if you think about Wireless continuing to run next year at about the same level, I think Wireline will come down, we are coming towards the end of the FiOS buildout. Directionally, I think overall, CapEx spending will come down in 2011 from 2010. I think we had tremendous discipline within the business around all of our CapEx spending, not only on core network but on systems and supporting infrastructure and we've also gotten much more efficient. A portion of our CapEx is labor, its not just material and we've got more efficient with that. So I think we're in a good position to continue posting very strong cash numbers and free cash flow numbers. Now on the upgrade level, we are very pleased with the upgrade level that 9.5% of our base upgraded in the quarter. Upgrades are a key focus for us and as I think about it, upgrades right now are all good, and will be all good for quite a while to come because a lot of times that the feature phone customer go into a smartphone customer. I'm willing to take that equipment to us in that subsidy what I'm getting two extra revenue so it's not an issue that we are concerned about, we're see it much more as an opportunity in providing upside to us in terms of revenue growth and profitability.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from David Barden with Bank of America-Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from David Barden with Bank of America-Merrill Lynch.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Two more if I could on FiOS. I'm sorry to beat that course little bit, John, but when we've been talking about kind of FiOS winding down, there's been a very specific number that we would save about $2 billion a year in Wireline CapEx. I guess it kinda so
componenttext: Two more if I could on FiOS. I'm sorry to beat that course little bit, John, but when we've been talking about kind of FiOS winding down, there's been a very specific number that we would save about $2 billion a year in Wireline CapEx. I guess it kinda sounds like maybe you're already starting to realize some of that as you've been winding that down maybe sooner than expected, so could you put more specifict numbers around, as this thing comes to an end in 2010, what the dollar savings should be for that project relative to the $2 billion you guys have been talking about for a couple of years? And the second part is, now that FiOS is 60% of the footprint and 50% of the revenue of the Wireline unit, could you give us more color about what are the margins now on this business and how does it's growth either benefit our dilute Wireline margins as we model that out into the next couple of years?

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have said in a couple of billion-dollar range, we are realizing some of that this year because we had been building at a $2 million premise passed roughly and we're going to build roughly $1 million this year. So in our program this year we've seen som
componenttext: We have said in a couple of billion-dollar range, we are realizing some of that this year because we had been building at a $2 million premise passed roughly and we're going to build roughly $1 million this year. So in our program this year we've seen some benefit there. We will continue to see that as we go into 2011 and 2012 but the message here is I think we've become more efficient with the capital spend, our cost per homes passed has been very good, we are very pleased with that and I think overall, I think the direction of CapEx spend will be down as we go into next year. From a margin perspective, we're very pleased with where we are. FiOS overall, we're very pleased with. We are up income positive year, we continue to grow that. This quarter because we ramped up and had more net adds than we had in previous quarters, that had some impact in terms of the ability to expand the margin in this particular quarter. It is overall accretive to the margins of the overall business, we don't put out specific numbers and we're not going to do that right now, Dave, but the good news here is we accelerated penetration with the changes Fran has really led putting in place, we feel we're in a better position from an acquisition standpoint. There's a lot more buzz around the FiOS capability and the quality of video, vis--vis our competition, so we think we're very well-positioned and FiOS is continuing to do well.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is that 50% of revenues in the Wireless business, is the margins in that higher or lower than the reported margins for the unit?
componenttext: Is that 50% of revenues in the Wireless business, is the margins in that higher or lower than the reported margins for the unit?

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's higher than the reported margins, Dave.
componenttext: It's higher than the reported margins, Dave.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from Brett Feldman of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question will come from Brett Feldman of Deutsche Bank.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: You got a question earlier about how you're seeing this ramp in smartphone adoption, yet we're still seeing really strong Wireless margin, and I think that, that has been surprising to a lot of people in that the adoption of smartphones have kind of compr
componenttext: You got a question earlier about how you're seeing this ramp in smartphone adoption, yet we're still seeing really strong Wireless margin, and I think that, that has been surprising to a lot of people in that the adoption of smartphones have kind of compressed margins in a lot of other operators first because you take subsidies upfront and then you started getting a lot of these sort of network abusers who are using more than what they are really paying for on their unlimited plan. So I guess sort of the question here is what could cause your margins to take a step backwards as we continue to scale in the data world. Could it be an investment you'd be willing to make in a new device category? Is there something incremental you would want to do on the network side that haven't done yet or really sketched out for us yet? Or do you think that you can continue to run at these record levels of EBITDA margins, even as you see accelerated usage of your data services?

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: As you know we're very pleased, Lowell McAdam who is our new President Chief and our Operating Officer likes to describe us as an and company not an or company, so it's both growth and profitability and we've always said that. The 47.2% is 157 basis point
componenttext: As you know we're very pleased, Lowell McAdam who is our new President Chief and our Operating Officer likes to describe us as an and company not an or company, so it's both growth and profitability and we've always said that. The 47.2% is 157 basis points up year-on-year, it's comparable sequentially. We believe that it really reflects the superior execution and scale advantage that our Wireless team has built over several years. We've built tremendous scale in that particular business, we're able to absorb more subsidy and continue to do really a very strong job on margin. Now a couple of pointes here I'd make is, this is a not one trick pony result. If you look at revenue we have a very nice improving revenue trends in the Wireless business. Service revenue in the fourth quarter was up 5%, first quarter 5.8%, second quarter 6.3%, third quarter 7.7% and that's only with 23% of our customers having smartphones today. So we believe as we go through the next several years and we go up that smartphone adoption, we're going to be able to grow revenue, grow profitability. We think our network is very well-positioned for the growth in data traffic, we put tremendous time and focus on this with Llowell and Tony Malone on making sure we're well-equipped. Our assumptions assume that our handset lineup that we think it's very strong today, where we be put all the emphasis on, again the Droid franchise and the Droid franchise is unique to Verizon, positions us very well and our handset lineup will get better over time. It's not going to take a step backwards, it will continue to be enhanced and is it possible we have a quarter where there's a knockout device that has some impact on margins? There's always a possibility of that happening, we've acknowledged that in the past and that would be a good thing to have happened because what you would do from a smartphone adoption in your overall ARPU. Now the other part of this is, our Wireless team not only focused on net adds and growth in ARPU, tremendous focus on driving efficiency in the business. They've been working on driving costs out of supply chain, you've seen the tremendous results they've have this year on lowering their inventory level. At the time you have new product introductions focused on driving costs out of customer service, driving more online interactions, eliminating things like other charges in credits, OCCs controlling them, retail store efficiency. So we think that scale we built from that business allows us to continue to have the lead in the industry on margins and we're not going to give that up.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Tim Horan with Oppenheim.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Tim Horan with Oppenheim.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: John, what do you think revenue can do over the next couple of years, you've obviously been accelerating, do you see the business as kind of a 3% , 4% revenue grower? And maybe related to that, how much did your wholesale pricing changes impact revenue in
componenttext: John, what do you think revenue can do over the next couple of years, you've obviously been accelerating, do you see the business as kind of a 3% , 4% revenue grower? And maybe related to that, how much did your wholesale pricing changes impact revenue in the quarter?

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Tim, generally, I absolutely think we can accelerate revenue growth from where we are today. I think the Wireless business, on a service ARPU at 7% can get up into high single digits and can touch 10% with data growth. The Wireline revenue picture looks a
componenttext: Tim, generally, I absolutely think we can accelerate revenue growth from where we are today. I think the Wireless business, on a service ARPU at 7% can get up into high single digits and can touch 10% with data growth. The Wireline revenue picture looks a little worse this quarter than it really is. We posted a number of 3.6% but the major driver on that, going a little bit worse from last quarter, was we made some price changes in our international wholesale business because we had certain routes out in the world that really weren't driving profitability. So when you look at our international wholesale revenue, it was down year-over-year by 28%. If you strip that out, our Wireline revenue was only down 2.4% versus the 3.6% that we reported and then as you cut under that, consumer is growing at the rate of 1.1%, we saw a better performance on small business, our enterprise revenue while it was negative .8%, if you break FX out, it was flat so the underlying trends even on the Wireline business are better than we think the 3.6% number would show and I think we believe we can get the Wireline business over the next couple of years with some help from the economy to flat and maybe to slightly growing and if we do that, that would be very important for the business overall because Fran's talked about, there's no question, we still have a lot of ability to drive more and more costs out but we have to get that business growing again and we're very focused on that and we think we can. But the Wireless business is going to be tremendous opportunity to continue to accelerate revenue growth in that business.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: You clearly have a premium network out there, do you think when you get the iPhone, you can charge a premium price out for the device or for the service or some kind of application sharing, I'm not asking when you're getting the iPhone but clearly there w
componenttext: You clearly have a premium network out there, do you think when you get the iPhone, you can charge a premium price out for the device or for the service or some kind of application sharing, I'm not asking when you're getting the iPhone but clearly there would be a huge benefit for subscribers being on your network versus your competitor?

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I talked earlier, Tim, about how we think about pricing, so we are very focused on the device lineup we have today. We think we have a great device lineup. With the Droid franchise has gone from nothing a year ago to where it really has a buzz and a lot o
componenttext: I talked earlier, Tim, about how we think about pricing, so we are very focused on the device lineup we have today. We think we have a great device lineup. With the Droid franchise has gone from nothing a year ago to where it really has a buzz and a lot of momentum out in the marketplace right now, from a pricing perspective we think the brand that we have build puts us in a unique position from a pricing perspective. We've always been bit of the premium and we think the brand will allow us to continue to do that.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question will come from Chris Larsen of Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Your next question will come from Chris Larsen of Piper Jaffray.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: A question back to FiOS, you obviously picked up some share or it appears based on what the cable has just said, that you picked up some share both on video and on data. My question is really there's been a lot of back-and-forth there, have you begun to s
componenttext: A question back to FiOS, you obviously picked up some share or it appears based on what the cable has just said, that you picked up some share both on video and on data. My question is really there's been a lot of back-and-forth there, have you begun to see anything so far in the fourth quarter that indicate the cable companies are getting more aggressive either on their video and their data pricing? And additionally, there were some comments made actually in the New York Post recently that are cables considering a massive increase or a material increase in their high-speed data prices to offset some of this over-the-top video that may be going on. If cable were to do that, is that something you guys would follow along with, that is a large increase or a material increase in your data pricing?

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Chris, a couple of thoughts here is the FiOS video business and Internet business, we've always said every quarter was very competitive business out there. I wouldn't say we've seen anything recently that changes the competitive landscape from an offer or
componenttext: Chris, a couple of thoughts here is the FiOS video business and Internet business, we've always said every quarter was very competitive business out there. I wouldn't say we've seen anything recently that changes the competitive landscape from an offer or a price perspective with the changes that Fran has led for us on the worry-free guarantee, the no contract, the focus on the MDU, we think we're in a very good position. We haven't planned any price changes here at this point in time, we would always continue to look at what's happening in the competitive landscape. We think our FiOS offering from based on the fiber end-to-end is a superior offering from a quality standpoint and we've been focused very much on acquisition and getting people to move, so we would continue to evaluate back end look at what the opportunity is to accelerate revenue growth.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your last question comes from James Ratcliffe of Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Your last question comes from James Ratcliffe of Barclays Capital.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Two if I could, one on capital structure and the other on FiOS. On the FiOs side for broadband, where are the adds coming from? The material portion in the past has been -- people being switched from DSL to FiOS is that continuing? And is the mix changing
componenttext: Two if I could, one on capital structure and the other on FiOS. On the FiOs side for broadband, where are the adds coming from? The material portion in the past has been -- people being switched from DSL to FiOS is that continuing? And is the mix changing in terms of DSL switches versus people coming from cable? And secondly on the capital structure side, if you're looking at dividend in cash up from Verizon Wireless, how much of a buffer do you have in terms of realized and tax proportional profits of Verizon Communications that haven't actually represented cash dividend apart from Wireless, so in other words how much could dividend up from VZW before you start to actually have to pay tax, incremental tax on those payments?

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me start out with the capital structure issue. We are very pleased with our cash performance. We think the Wireless business, you can see it's a cash machine, the cash generation of that business is not going to decelerate, if anything it's going to a
componenttext: Let me start out with the capital structure issue. We are very pleased with our cash performance. We think the Wireless business, you can see it's a cash machine, the cash generation of that business is not going to decelerate, if anything it's going to accelerate. We are in a very good position from that perspective. We believe that buys and dividend is extremely safe. There's not a major tax issue here that I'm worried about that's going to have some impact on us. So we think we're in a good position. Fran and his team has had a lot of focus on trying to make the Wireline business more free cash flow positive, we'll continue to work at that but our cash flow margin is in a very good position and you can see it from this quarter. Fran will comment on the FiOS question.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the migration question. Yes, we continue to migrate some of our former DSL customers into the FiOS broadband but if you look at our net adds, if you take the Internet net adds from FiOS product less our DSL, we're still on a positive pay share perspect
componenttext: On the migration question. Yes, we continue to migrate some of our former DSL customers into the FiOS broadband but if you look at our net adds, if you take the Internet net adds from FiOS product less our DSL, we're still on a positive pay share perspective. The other thing to consider, too, is that when you look at the penetration of our Internet at 31 and our TV at 27, what we find is once we convert someone over to our FiOS Internet product with the speed that we have and the amazement that they get from that, it's very easy for us to then walk in behind that and convert over the TV because we can bundle it and save them money. So I think, we do have migration from DSL but we're also taking share.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I hope you can see that we feel very positive about the performance of the business this quarter. We had given you some direction that we felt we needed to do about where earnings would be in the second half of the year and in this quarter we're at the ve
componenttext: I hope you can see that we feel very positive about the performance of the business this quarter. We had given you some direction that we felt we needed to do about where earnings would be in the second half of the year and in this quarter we're at the very high end of that range. That's our focus for the fourth quarter, we will continue delivering the fourth quarter the kinds of things we delivered here, strong Wireless results driven by continuing ARPU acceleration and stronger smartphone results. We established the Wireline business from a margin position, we've actually expanded them slightly in this quarter. We believe that will accelerate as we get into the fourth quarter and our cash flow position is very strong and we'll remain very strong. So I thank you for taking the time. I'll pass it back to John just to close up the call.

headline: Verizon Communications Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2010
